indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Multi-sectoral and gender-sensitive response framework to HIV and AIDS in place. 2. # of sectors equipped with coordination tools and skills, and integrated in national coordination framework. 3. # of sectors receiving mentorship in comprehensive programme management. 4. A human rights-based and gender sensitive HIV and AIDS response strategy in place. 5. # of decentralized NERCHA structures and non-state actors equipped with skills in financial management, programme development, implementation and monitoring and resource mobilization.

baseline.comment: 1. 2010- National Coordination Framework in place but not fully operational. 2. 2009: Capacity Needs Assessment of sectors conducted by NERCHA. Sectors not equipped with coordination tools and skills and an integrated national coordination framework. 3. Limited mentorship interventions for comprehensive programme management 4. No human rights-based and gender sensitive HIV and AIDS response strategy in place. 5. Limited capacity of non-state actors to effectively manage and account for resources provided by NERCHA and development partners

target.comment: 1. One SPAFA meeting supported. 2. SWABCHA Members M&E skills strengthened. 3. Government Ministries assessed for HIV mainstreaming. 4.Legal Environment Action plan developed. 5. Advocacy Initiatives for most risk populations (MARPS) enhanced. 6. Draft Policy on National Volunteerism

actual.comment: 1. One NERCHA High level meeting held with the Prime Minister to launch the Extended National Strategic Framework and NERCHA strategy. 2. 22 Private Sector (SWABCHA) Wellness coordinators trained on Monitoring and evaluation and introduced to the electronic Management system. Five companies have been enrolled into the system. 3. Mainstreaming of HIV into the Public Sector is presently being piloted in six ministries funded through SADC project. Assessment of six other Ministries deferred to 2015 pending availability of resources. 4. Legal Environment Assessment report completed currently being edited. 5. LEA Report presented to most at risk population and advocacy strategies identified for more inclusive approach. 6. Limited government ownership for National voluntarism policy, more advocacy required. 7. 17 new Board members and strategic committee members of the Swaziland Association of Visually Impaired Persons (SAVIP) were capacitated on HIV and eNSF and their role in the national HIV response. 8. Over 30 Ministry of Health Pharmacist were capacitated on TRIPS and access to Medicines. This was jointly supported with SARPHAM

target.comment: 1.Capacity for mainstreaming Gender and Human Rights into development plans and EIA processes strengthened. 2. Gap analysis of the EIA Legislation to identify opportunities for integrating HIV, gender and human rights in the EIA processes. 3. Develop a simplified version for mainstreaming gender into Human rights into HIV programmes. 4. HIV mainstreaming framework developed 5. Survey on PSHACC service delivery and the uptake of HIV Mainstreaming into public sector conducted. 6. Public and Private Sector Wellness Policy and guidelines developed.

actual.comment: 1.Over 100 government and private national consultants were capacitated on the mainstreaming of gender and human rights into the Environment Impact Assessment processes including the appropriate techniques for presenting issues on the EIA reports. 2.Leveraging on resources from the environment Pillar the EIA regulations were reviewed to include social issues. The regulations have been adopted for approval through the appropriate government structures. The Swaziland Environment Authority has committed to commence implementation of the regulations in 2016. 3/4Developing a simplified version of mainstreaming gender into Human rights into HIV programmes and a public sector mainstreaming guide was re-phased to 2016 5. Conducting a baseline for the public sector wellness programme has been re-phased to 2016 due to the required financial resources to undertake this exercise. 6. The review of public and private sector wellness policy and guidelines was conducted. This resulted on the adoption of comprehensive wellness programme and 5% budget allocation for HIV and wellness programmes including the need to develop a comprehensive policy.

iati-activity.title: Strengthening National Capacities for Poverty Reduction
iati-activity.description: To support the development of evidence policy development, capacity development for data generation, women economic empowernment through promotion of entreprenuership and sustainable business management.

iati-activity.title: Strength. Nat. Cap. Poverty
iati-activity.description: Development of national frameworks including policies, systems and processes that promote the access and effective utilization of productive resources by the poor is key in the project implemntation.

target.comment: 1. Greater engagement of national stakeholders on climate change policy issues to promote better coordination, sharing of information and solutions at all levels (transboundary, national and sectoral). 2. Capacity for climate change risks identification and management integrated in national investment programmes - KDDP and LUSIP 3. Vulnerable communities' capacity to pilot and upscale climate change adaptation options enhanced: Number of schools/ teachers trained in integrated water harvesting; Number of sand dams constructed to enhance communities productivity; Number of boreholes drilled for vulnerable communities; pilot crop diversification, and; Number of initiatives promoting ecosystems land management.

actual.comment: Increased national stakeholders interactions and undertaking on climate change adaptation (CCA) in the water sector were facilitated for improved coordination, sharing of information and solutions at various levels. This was achieved through support for two (2) national dialogues which discussed climate change policy strategies and awareness mechanisms to facilitate adaptation by vulnerable communities. Policy recommendations were made for the development of the draft National Climate Change Policy document. Another level that noted increased engagement on climate change adaptation issues for influence on policy issues was at the community level where the project embarked on pilot demonstrations for water harvesting and storage, creating awareness and practice of CCA by the affected communities. Enhanced integration of climate change risk management was facilitated with major investment initiatives in the agricultural sector, in the country, the Komati Basin Water Authority (KOBWA), Komati Downstream Development Programme (KDDP), and the Lower Usuthu Swaziland Irrigation Programme (LUSIP. This included development of the emergency preparedness for the 3 major dams in the country, Maguga under KOBWA and Mnjoli under the Department of Water Affairs, and Lubovane under LUSIP. Further support resulted in the production of the training needs assessment report for the LUSIP and SWADE programmes, development of the agriculture, water and sugarcane Training Modules on sectoral climate change integration. The support also culminated in training on the mainstreaming of climate change for 30 officers from the institutions. Following the construction of the integrated water harvesting infrastructure in the 10 schools in 2013, seven (7) also received support through drilling of boreholes. The project then facilitated further uptake of the technology by the school community (teachers and students) and the surrounding community. One hundred and thirty-seven (137) were teachers

target.comment: 1. Rural vulnerable communities' livelihood capacities strengthened through integration of sustainable development in local initiatives. 2. Ecosystems restoration pilot project in place. 3. Increased capacity for climate change adaptation in transboundary settings for the national negotiations team. 4. Enhanced climate change adaptation advocacy: communication products and World Water Day

actual.comment:
1 and 2: One pilot site provided for community ownership of Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) practice through the restoration of an ecosystem. The cleared land is used by 56 community members to undertake income-generation activities such nursery for indigenous trees and bee-keeping.
3. Mainstreaming of CC Risks into National Policies Report was produced. UNDP supported the reengineering for high-level (HL) engagement by the country in the transboundary and national water resources management. The Position Paper for the Swaziland Tripartite Partnership Technical Committee (TPTC) was produced, which instrument was enabled by the Climate Change Impacts Assessment Transboundary Water Resources Management Report bringing recommendations for presentation in the next sitting of the TPTC (South Africa and Mozambique) for CCA integrated policy reform.
4. Advocacy and awareness creation on climate change adaptation (CCA) and its linkages with sustainable development was demonstrated during the World Water Day. Awareness for rural communities for adoption of practices through water harvesting was promoted for example the sand dams supply to the local clinic was demonstrated at KaBhudla community. Further demonstration were on the sand dams supplying for water for vegetable growing.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1.3: Institutional needs for inter-sectoral cooperation identified (through national dialogue - Output 1.2), appropriate national inter-sectoral coordination mechanism clearly defined, establishment/ strengthening of national coordination mechanism supported and capacity of key staff/ stakeholders strengthened through at least three (3) targeted training courses on inter-sectoral coordination

baseline.comment: 1.3 Inter-sectoral coordination needs and mechanisms not clearly defined, National Climate Change Committee not gazetted and with limited competencies to guide adaptation option in the country.

target.comment: 1.3: Institutional needs for inter-sectoral cooperation identified (through national dialogue - Output 1.2), appropriate national inter-sectoral coordination mechanism clearly defined, establishment/ strengthening of national coordination mechanism supported and capacity of key staff/ stakeholders strengthened through at least three (3) targeted training courses on inter-sectoral coordination

actual.comment:
The key outputs of this activity were mostly achieved in the 2014/15 reporting period.
During this reporting period, the Project has facilitated greater integration of the water sector issues in the work of the National Climate Change Committee and further develop plans to incorporate climate change in a sector wide approach.
The project has strengthened the coordination and inclusion of climate change into the sector wide approach within the Ministry of Natural Resources and Energy.
The Ministry of Natural Resources and Energy has further established a coordinated reporting system for which climate change is one of the key pillars feeding into the National Planning and Reporting Processes and frameworks in the Ministry of Natural Resources and Energy.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Promote the implementation of national and trans-boundary integrated water resource management that is sustainable and equitable given expected climate change.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Institutional capacity for climate change adaptation strengthened through the integration of climate change risks into national water resources management policies and the establishment of inter-sectoral- coordination mechanims based on inclusive and informed national dialogue

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1.1: Key scientific knowledge gaps on climate change impacts within the water sector defined, targeted research to fill knowledge gaps carried out, climate change response options identified, and main findings and strategic recommendations disseminated to at least twenty (20) relevant organisations across sectors (incl. KOBWA, MNRE, MoA, MoEPD, MoF, MoH, MoPSI, MTEA, NCCC, NDMA, NMS, NWA, RBAs, SEA, SWADE, SZWP, TPTC)

baseline.comment: 1.1 Information in Swaziland on climate change risks and possible impacts is scarce, particularly regarding flood vulnerability, groundwater potential and crop diversification options

target.comment: 1.1: Key scientific knowledge gaps on climate change impacts within the water sector defined, targeted research to fill knowledge gaps carried out, climate change response options identified, and main findings and strategic recommendations disseminated to at least twenty (20) relevant organisations across sectors (incl. KOBWA, MNRE, MoA, MoEPD, MoF, MoH, MoPSI, MTEA, NCCC, NDMA, NMS, NWA, RBAs, SEA, SWADE, SZWP, TPTC)

actual.comment:
The key baseline studies and knowledge gaps on climate change impacts for the water sector were conducted and completed during the 2013/14 reporting period. The Third National Communications to the UNFCCC for Swaziland supported by UNEP analytic base has already benefitted from the 2014 CC Vulnerability Assessment Report facilitated by the Project. Information packaging is currently underway through the development of abridged versions and new products for different users in particular, decision makers, the various technical institutions, vulnerable community members and women. These will be shared with stakeholders in various platforms such as meetings, public offices, electronically and through the webpage. The products include:
Summarized versions of all the key project reports (the vulnerability assessment, crop diversification study, groundwater study and policy and institutional dialogues report)
Project Policy brief report based on report outcomes.
Lessons learnt report
Technical Knowledge sharing products in both English and local language (Siswati): through pamphlets, brochures for sand dams, rainwater harvesting and ecosystem restoration
Development of a video on sand dams construction, maintenance and use.
Development of a scientific paper on sand dams technology for information sharing with the academia and other partners.
This will increase the visibility of the project and spread the successful story of the project impacts. The Outputs will also be shared in both the UNDP website and the Government (DWA) new project website currently being developed. The targeted institutions include: KOBWA, MNRE, MoA, MoEPD, MoF, MoH, MoPSI, MTEA, NCCC, NDMA, NMS, NWA, RBAs, SEA, SWADE, SZWP, TPTC). Some of the products will target other stakeholders like communities and local traditional leaders.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 1.2: A set of tailor-made climate change response measures related to national (and trans-boundary) water management identified and integrated into at least three (3) national level policies related to water resources management (e.g. NWP, IWRMP, draft National Climate Change Policy) through a series of national policy dialogue workshops (incl. with organisations listed under Output 1.1 and using strategic recommendations from that output)

baseline.comment: 1.2 Key national policies do not, or not adequately, consider climate change

target.comment: 1.2: A set of tailor-made climate change response measures related to national (and trans-boundary) water management identified and integrated into at least three (3) national level policies related to water resources management (e.g. NWP, IWRMP, draft National Climate Change Policy) through a series of national policy dialogue workshops (incl. with organisations listed under Output 1.1 and using strategic recommendations from that output)

actual.comment:
1.2.1 - The project has facilitated climate change issues in the water sector in overall. The climate change response measures that were identified in a participatory manner involving all key stakeholders culminated into the drafting of policy statements for inclusion in the water sector related policies. The scientific evidence and outputs of the project vulnerability assessments were used as a reference point in the formulation of the following policies:
Final draft of the Climate Change Policy developed in 2014.
Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan 2014-2018 incorporating adaptation measures for the water sector completed in 2013/14.
Policy statements on climate change adaptation for inclusion in the following water sector strategic documents were developed: 2003 National Water Policy and the IWRM Master Plan. These statement briefs are utilized by the DWA in a review process for integration of climate change through an EU funded project. The Emergency Preparedness Plans for the major dams in Swaziland Reports were produced .These are currently being utilized by the DWA to inform the new country Dam Safety Regulations that are under formulation. The project outputs have also been instrumental in informing the drafting of the Third National Communication to the UNFCCC and the Intended National Determined Contributions (INDCs) Report to be submitted to UN in October. The PMU serves in the technical working group to facilitate supply of climate change adaptation and mitigation information for the water sector.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Climate change risk management measures integrated into national water and agricultural programmes and implemented in pilot projects to promote adaptation on the ground

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 2.1: Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change risks into key national policies (NWP, IWRMP, NCCP) developed, toolkits on practical application of climate change response measures (identified through Output 1.2) developed and at least five (5) targeted training courses on toolkit application delivered

baseline.comment: 2.1 Key national policies do not, or not adequately, consider climate change and inadequate knowledge on practical implementation of climate change response measures

target.comment: 2.1: Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change risks into key national policies (NWP, IWRMP, NCCP) developed, toolkits on practical application of climate change response measures (identified through Output 1.2) developed and at least five (5) targeted training courses on toolkit application delivered

actual.comment:
2.1.1 - 2.1.3 The final guidelines for mainstreaming climate change and toolkits for practical implementation of climate for the water and land use sector were developed and finalised in collaboration with the key stakeholders. Recommendations for Policy statements for climate change mainstreaming were developed for inclusion into the following national policies:
Water sector policies (IWRM Master Plan, National Water Policy
National Land Policy
Review of the Environment Impact Assessment Regulatory Framework
Comprehensive Agricultural Sector Policy
In addition, various tools for practical application of climate change response measures for water and land use were developed. The tools included: Digital agriculture & amp; Land use Toolkit Version 1.0 December 2014; The Climate Mapper; CRISTAL; Climate Vulnerability and Capacity Analysis Tool (cvca); Climate Change Monitoring Tool; WEAP; Mike Basin; SCADA; and,Standard Precipitation Index 40. Upon validation of the reports, stakeholders were engaged in a training on the practical use of these tools to foster understanding and technical skilling.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.2: Programme/ project specific climate change risks and tailor-made response measures identified and integrated into at least three (3) major management/ investment plans implemented in Swaziland (incl. KDDP, LUSIP and CDPs developed under the FAO-GEF SLM programme implemented by SWADE)

baseline.comment: 2.2 Climate change risks and possible response measures at present not considered in national management/ investment plans

target.comment: 2.2: Programme/ project specific climate change risks and tailor-made response measures identified and integrated into at least three (3) major management/ investment plans implemented in Swaziland (incl. KDDP, LUSIP and CDPs developed under the FAO-GEF SLM programme implemented by SWADE)

actual.comment:
Increased resilience for the sugar industry, which accounts for a significant proportion of the GDP (18-21% of the GDP) has been climate-proofed. The project has successfully identified specific climate change risks and tailor made response measures for the three major investments in Swaziland through the development of Emergency Preparedness Plans (drought and floods) for the three major dam infrastructures in Swaziland; Maguga, Mjoli and Lubovane Dams for KOBWA, Komati Downstream Development Project (KDDP) and the LUSIP project, respectively.
The intervention aimed at building the capacities for risk management with focus on improving the technical staff and downstream communities awareness on the future anticipated impacts of climate change. This has culminated into the development of Dam Safety Regulations for the major Dams operated by the three institutions, highlighted above.
Through the project interventions, climate change tailor made response measures were recommended for the two SWADE projects (LUSIP and KDDP) and also for the LUSIP-GEF project community Development Plans. A number of climate change recommendations for each investment plan was identified for implementation by SWADE and other key stakeholders. These recommendations were discussed with senior management of SWADE in order to develop an action plan to address a responsive undertaking towards mitigating potential impacts. The commitment demonstrated by SWADE to address the recommendations was evident in translating lessons into the development of the chiefdom development plans and environment mitigation plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 2.3: Capacity of key stakeholders and water resources management and/or agricultural development practitioners to integrate climate change risks into their activities strengthened by incorporating the climate risks/responses measures (identified under Output 2.2) into the ongoing training courses offerd as part of ongoing national programmes (e.g. KDDP, LUSIP).

baseline.comment: 2.3 Knowledge and awareness of climate change risks is very low and climate change risk is not adequately considered in ongoing implementation of ongoing activities

target.comment: 2.3: i) Climate change adaptation modules developed for train-the-trainers courses based on risks/responses identified under Output 2.2 to raise trainers awareness and capacity on CCA; ii) at least two forthcoming training courses are strengthened through the inclusion of CCA modules in the training materials, and iii) strengthened training courses offered to build awareness and capacity of practitioners

actual.comment:
Fifteen (15) new climate change adaptation modules were developed under Output 2.2. About 13 of the modules are dealing with agricultural extension and agribusiness, incorporating climate smart agriculture (CSA) practices and new agronomic practices in the light of climate change. The modules also focus on the key cash crops that are produced in the country in light of the diversification options: Cassava, vegetables etc. Some of the modules focused on IWRM management and improving irrigation efficiency at the farm level as well as rainwater harvesting in and outside the farm. An environmental module was also developed focusing on the environmental aspects in the project.
A consultative approach was utilised in the development of the climate smart modules to be utilised through a Training of Trainers modality, however some modules would have to facilitate a contact modality, in particular training of the farmers. Thirty-five (35) SWADE Trainers, composed of community environmental officers and SWADE agricultural extension officers were trained on the modules which was also open for the communities' lead farmers. The trainings were not only limited to the modules but also covered the aspects of revised chiefdom development plans guidelines taking into account climate change impacts.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 2.4: Community based climate resilience projects implemented in pilot sites, including the installation of rainwater harvesting systems in at least four (4) identified communities/ areas and rainwater infiltration improvement schemes (incl. reforestation) in at least four (4) communities/areas

baseline.comment: 2.4 Climate change risk awareness and adaptation capacity at community level is very low

actual.comment:
2.4.1/2: The impacts of the rainwater harvesting systems installed in schools and communities were monitored during the reporting period together with the lessons documentation. The activities also included training in six (6) schools for teachers, students, school committees, constituency leaders, community health motivators, community water management committees and traditional community leaders. In total there were 256 trained people of which 58% were women. The training did not only focus on rainwater harvesting but also considered an integrated approach to environmental and natural resources management. Knowledge sharing and good practice was instilled among the school children through establishment of schools water, sanitation and environmental groups to champion the management of the harvested water and productive use of excess and waste water through fruit tree growing (the trees were also provided by the project)
Key impacts that are monitored include: improvement on sanitation issues (diahorreal reports at neighboring clinics), absenteeisms due to water related challenges, and this will also be included in the lessons learnt documentation under development.
2.4.3/5: The community capacities for ecosystem restoration continue being enabled on the ground. The activities achieved and completed so far include: Integrated approach to removal of Alien invasive plans covering an area more than 50ha; Artificial means to improve rainwater infiltration through trenching and terracing; Establishment of livelihood projects that are climate smart and less dependent on natural resources such as, establishment of vegetable nursery, fruit tree plantation integrated with bee keeping, and; 5ha drip irrigation and fish production.
Ownership of the intervention continues being embedded in community participation. Partnership with other institutions such as the National Agricultural Marketing Board (NAMBoard) has been established to provide sustainable extension and marketing services to the community schemes as well as Ministry of Agriculture extension department and non-government organization - World Vision for continued providing of support to the community. The project is also providing continuous training in leadership to foster sustainability, in particular for the participating women.

target.comment: Install Basic Weather Station at LUSIP Phase 1 and KDDP

actual.comment:
2.4.6 -The installation of the automated weather stations at the two project sites (LUSIP 1 and KDDP) was completed 2013/14. The purpose of the stations was to expand the data availability to farmers can use for planning for climate change and also provide data for early warning systems. The collected data has been linked to National Grid at the National Meteorological Service (MET) and has contributed to the expansion of the national weather stations network. The stations have generated reliable climate and weather data for the past two years, increasing MET's capacity to provide consistent meteorological services to its users in particular as the country intends to conduct modelling scenarios. The stations have also been coded and linked with the South African Weather stations and these are known as (Sihhoye and Lubovane Weather Stations). The Data that is obtained from these stations include: Temperature, Sunshine, Relative humidity, Pressure, Rainfall, Wind speed and direction and evaporation data. All the data is automated except for the evaporation data. A data backup system has also been upgraded by the project at the National Meteorological Service through the mobile network, making it easier and more cost-effective to collect and monitor inconsistences. The MET technicians have been trained on the system and linked to the South African Weather Service for continuous support and maintenance of the stations. The Government of Swaziland has also set aside a budget for the continuous maintenance of the system. In addition to the installed instruments, the project provided additional spare parts tools that can run the system for the next 5 years.
2.4.7 The development of curriculum for schools has been left as a prerogative of the National Meteorological Office which is responsible for climate change coordination at National Level. The Project Board and Technical Committee recommended that this activity be led by the NMS and the project provide the resources. The MTR recommended that if the NMS is not able to utilize the funds by year end, the resources will be re-allocated to another activity. The Project however has continued to lobby the NMS to conduct the activity. The National Curriculum Centre provisionally agreed to engage on this activity and the process is at its infancy.

baseline.comment: No CCA measures that increase water security by the utilization of a sand dam have been tested in Swaziland.

target.comment: Determine feasibility sites for the installation of sand dams and to construct at least 5 pilot dams

actual.comment:
2.4.2 - The project has successfully piloted 5 sand dams across the driest areas in the Lowveld of Swaziland. The two outstanding Dams at Sitilo and Sigwe were completed during the reporting period. The total estimated beneficiaries are 6,711 of which 52% are women. The sand dams have been very key in highlighting CCA in the country. Close collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) and Department of Water Affairs (DWA) as well as with the five communities that participated and contributed towards their establishment in both monetary contributions and providing labor. The existing collaboration of the MOA and DWA has yielded positively on the impact even at political levels. The Minister of Agriculture and Minister of Natural Resources and Energy have officially embraced this technology through an official opening during the 2015 World Water Day Commemoration event that was held at the Mafutseni (for the KaBhudla Sand Dam) where there was demonstrated linkages between the water and health sectors. The sand dams has facilitated water supply to the newly constructed KaBhudla Clinic. The DWA is continuing to provide the necessary monitoring of the water quality through laboratory analysis of the water and also monitoring the water quantity. The communities are being assisted to put up a proposal for Government to fund pumping of the water from the dams and provide it for both establishment drip irrigated gardens and for potable water supply to the various surrounding communities.
The lessons learnt and full scale impact including a gender analysis report is still being conducted for future reporting.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Negotiations on trans-boundary water management for the Incomati, Maputo and Umbeluzi river basins informed by climate change risk analysis.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 3.1: Climate change impacts on trans-boundary water resource management (TWRM) and negotiation options assessed, tailor-made (short-, mid- and long-term) TWRM strategy paper for Swaziland developed through consultations with key stakeholders (as integral part of national policy dialogue - Output 1.2) and position paper for Swaziland TWRM negotation team(s) jointly developed (with negotiators)

baseline.comment: 3.1 Present water agreements (on Incomati, Maputo) do not adequately address climate change and adaptation

target.comment: 3.1: Climate change impacts on trans-boundary water resource management (TWRM) and negotiation options assessed, tailor-made (short-, mid- and long-term) TWRM strategy paper for Swaziland developed through consultations with key stakeholders (as integral part of national policy dialogue - Output 1.2) and position paper for Swaziland TWRM negotation team(s) jointly developed (with negotiators)

actual.comment: 3.1.1 - 3.2.2 The project has continued to engage with the TPTC and negotiating bodies at national level. A consensus has been reached that this component is very essential both within the country and at the transboundary level. The project has facilitated the engagement of both local and international consultants to assist in developing the position and strategy paper informing the delegation to the TPTC. A model for water and demand management is currently being established for the three major basins (Komati, Mbuluzi and Usuthu). Data collection is underway among the various entities and institutions. The inception phase of the study has been completed. The team of consultants are currently working on the modelling of various climate change scenarios that will inform the position of the country and further inform the strategy that will focus the country on CCA IWRM, as well as conducting stakeholders consultation at various levels including the transboundary levels. The final outputs are expected in October 2015, upon which the engagement of the riparian countries to discuss the outcome will be solicited. The process has received political support from the Minister of Natural Resources and Energy. The capacity of the TPTC negotiating team will also be built through training through utilization of the project outputs like the climate change vulnerability assessment for the water sector and infrastructure.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 3.2: Targeted information briefs on projected climate change impacts on TWRM developed and disseminated to senior decision-makers in at least twenty (20) relevant organisations, including key water user groups

baseline.comment: 3.2 Stakeholder knowledge and awareness on climate change impacts on TWRM is very limited

target.comment: 3.2: Targeted information briefs on projected climate change impacts on TWRM developed and disseminated to senior decision-makers in at least twenty (20) relevant organisations, including key water user groups

actual.comment: 3.2.1 -3.2.2 The project has continued to provide the necessary information briefs to the government, key institutions and national stakeholders. Leadership of the 2015 World Water Day by DWA was facilitated through by Project resulting in information through pamphlets, print media articles on the importance of water to the achievement of MDGs and sustainable development. The project has developed a lessons learnt report that has been shared with the key stakeholders. A consultant has been engaged to focus on the development and packaging of the information sharing documents. The Inception report for the communication strategy has been adopted. The project will develop abridged versions of all the reports produced by the project consultants and document lessons from all the project interventions for sharing with stakeholders at various levels and platforms. Information will also be shared electronically through a webpage, and on Facebook, YouTube and twitter. A scientific research paper on the sand dams work done by the project is also being packaged as part of the information sharing to stakeholders.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. National Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan in place by 2013 2. National Climate Change Policy in place by 2014 3. Number of community resilience initaitives supported: National Disaster Simulation Excercise, World Disaster Day etc 4. Number of national capacity building intiatives for enhanced management and monitoring of natural resources.

baseline.comment: 1. Limited enabling environment for national climate change undertaking: no national frameworks or ingration of climate change into sectoral approches. 2. Disaster risk management not promoted fully: limited resources. 3. Limited capacity to manage natural resources sustainably.

target.comment: 1. Finalised National Climate Change Policy 2. Operationalised National Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan 2014-2019 to promote climate change adaptation options and low carbon emmission development path. 3. Finalised and operationalised Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) Initiative Gap Analysis Report and Action Plan promoting energy efficiencies and renewable energy initiatives. 4. Advocacy for devolution of international, regional and national instruments for climate change, biodiversity, energy and disaster risk reduction

actual.comment: The overarching national guidance to the climate change agenda was facilitated through support for the drafting of the National Climate Change Policy. The process was informed by national stakeholders consultations under the leadership of the National Climate Change Committee (NCCC). The NCCC was further supported to develop a monitoring framework for the implementation of the National Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan 2014-2019. Such support contributed to increased prioritisation of climate change, variability and associated risks and their impact to sustainable development. This also led to the integration of CC into the revised national development strategy, Vision 2022. Following support for the completion of the Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) Initiative Gap Analysis Report and Action Plan for 2014 to 2030 the Actions Agenda development was initiated by Department of Energy for sectoral resource mobilisation and scheduling of the national Energy/Renewable Energy programmes in the country. Increased capacity for adherence to international, regional and national instruments for climate change, biodiversity, energy and disaster risk reduction was enhanced through support during the World Environment Day, World Energy Day and the World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) national consultations - advocacy activities involved the participation of school children in knowledge sharing for activities that contribute to decrease of carbon emissions and UNDP coordinating the United National Disaster Team in supporting the National Disaster Management Agency lead the production of the national WHS Report and its input to the Eastern and Southern Africa WHS Report.

target.comment: 1. National Climate Change Policy approved 2. Environmental Education Association of Southern Africa Regional Conference supported. 3. Strategic Environment Impact Assessment and Audit Regulations reviewed 4. Advocacy and resources mobilisation for adaptation, mitigation and waste management and the SE4All initiatives 5. National Climate Change Committee programme management capacities enhanced.

actual.comment:
1. The National Climate Change Policy draft approved by the Ministry of Tourism and Environmental Affairs (MTEA) increased the resilience road-mapping response to the impact of climate change and variability in the country. The Policy also proposes institutional arrangement and management of climate finance strengthening the readiness of the country to receive, utilize and account for the global resources.
2. The participation of the youth in the regional environmental management was promoted through support for the 2015 Environment Education Association of Southern Africa Regional Conference hosted by the Swaziland Environmental Authority (SEA) in September 2015. The Conference highlighted the need to prioritize programmes promoting professional inclusion of the youth, within the catalytic role of the environment as a service to sustainable development (jobs and entrepreneurship).
3. The Environment Impact Assessment and Environment Audit Regulations were reviewed. The new Regulation Frameworks enabled the integration of social, gender and HIV and AIDS in all the development plan, in particular large projects and programmes. The review facilitated the Swaziland Environment Authority cost-recovery through the EIA fees review as well as provided guidance on the undertaking of Strategic EIA.
4. The Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) Gap Analysis Report and Action Plan 2014-2030 was approved by the Government of Swaziland resulting in a HL launch that created awareness on the use of Renewable Energy for production of electricity. The Report launch was undertaken together with the 2014 Renewables Readiness Assessment (RRA) Report for Swaziland supported by the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA).
The SE4ALL Investment Prospectus and the Actions Agenda (IP-AA) draft has been prepared and subjected to the Quality Assurance review by the Regional Hub. Further consultations have been suggested with the investors and the private sector.
5. The capacity of

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Inter-Cluster coordination systems are better able to coordinate and respond to disasters 2. % of local government authorities who have contingency and multi-hazards plans. 3. Extent to which National Early Warning Systems gather and provide information to disaster prone community. 4. % of regional and local community who have mitigation and early recovery interventions to minimize the effects of natural and man-made disasters. 5. Disaster prevention and management infrastructure - vehicles, national situation room and regional disaster centres, rapid assessment tools

baseline.comment: 1.1 2011: National Disaster Risk Management Policy 1.2. 2012: No Decentralized DRR Structures

target.comment: 1. National simulation of multi- hazard national plans developed promoting the sectoral response to disaster prevention and management. 2. National Early Warning Review Assessment Report, and National Situation Room and Regional Disaster Warning Centers refurbished for generation and dissemination of Early Warning information. 3. Country exchange learning undertaken, rapid assessment tools standardized, SOP developed and risk maps developed all contributing to a well coordinated national simulation exercise and increased adequacy of the national machinery to manage disasters at all levels.

actual.comment: Building the capacity for the most-at-risk taking informed actions during hazardous events, UNDP facilitated national simulation exercises for five (5) chiefdoms reaching out to over 5,500 rural communities members. While on the other hand support provided for the revision of the multi- hazard national plans increased the national coordination capacities for the National Disaster Management Agency (NDMA) and three (3) multi-sectoral Regional Development Teams (RDT). One hundred and thirty-seven (137) RDT members were trained in rapid assessment undertaking. Risk mapping and profiling of national hazards was also undertaken in two (2) out of the four (4) regions in the country. The concerted effort lead to decreased responsive time for the NDMA (three working days for relief support to be availed in affected communities) as well as more efficient mechanisms being employed for collection of post-hazard data and information through the use of standardized rapid assessment tools. National preparedness was further enhanced through the production of the National Early Warning Review Assessment Report, and refurbishment of two (2) Regional Disaster Warning Centers for generation and dissemination of Early Warning information.

target.comment: 1. National Situational Room (NSR) completed and the necessary equipment purchased. 2. Standard Operational Procedures for NSR in place. 3. Manzini Regional Development Team - Disaster Risk Management Team in place 4. National capacities for DRM enhanced - revision of the Multi-hazard national plan

actual.comment:
1. National capacities for Disaster Risk Management (DRM) was supported through the construction of the National Situation Room and the four (4) Regional Centres.
2. The Standard Operating Procedures were prioritized for 2016 due to the prioritized restructuring exercise at the National Disaster Management Agency (NDMA)
3.The devolution of management of disaster in the country was facilitated to sub-regional level through the establishment of the remaining Manzini Regional Development Disaster Risk Management Team. Further strengthening of the coordination and establishment of linkages with the national entity, NDMA has been prioritized for 2016.
4. The 2012-14 Multi Cluster Hazard Plan was reviewed resulting in the 2015 to 2017 DRM road map with strengthened integration of gender issues, HIV and AIDS and Sexual Reproduction Health and introduction of a new Environment Cluster.
